page.title: Modern Art Research Institute of Ukrainian Academy of Arts

revision.text:
[[File:MODERN ART RESEARCH INSTITUTE gallery 2.jpg|thumb|right|400px|Modern Art Research Institute]] '''Modern Art Research Institute of [[Ukrainian Academy of Arts]]''' ({{lang-ua|Інститут Проблем Cучасного Mистецтва України}}) is a unique institute in Ukraine that exercises the fundamental scientific researches in the field of all kinds of the [[Contemporary art|modern art]], the practical and search studios directed on development of the professional modern art and architecture, the adoption of new creative technologies, the formation of national culture, the preparation and the edition of monographies and scientific papers of the principal directions of scientific activity.<ref>The Messenger of Ukrainian Academy of Arts (Вісник Академії мистецтв України.) -- К., 2007.</ref>
It was found in December 2001, under the auspices of the Ministry of culture and art of Ukraine, the vice-president НАН of Ukraine I. F. Kuras, the vice-prime-minister of Ukraine (humanitarian dept.) V. P. Seminojenko.<ref>Enactment of the Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine № 578-р, 13.12.2001</ref>
== Functions ==
* Systematization of information on the new world developments and researches in all fields of art, * Monitoring of activity of cultural institutions and the analysis of results, * Scientific researches into the theory and history of culture in general and from the point of view of detection of universal laws of historical manifestations, evolution and functioning in the modern world of hypertechnologies.
== Leadership ==
* Director — [[Victor Sydorenko|V. Sydorenko]], PhD, prof. * Deputy director (scientific dept.) — A. Puchkov, DSc, prof. * Deputy director (economy dept.) — A. Babich, * Deputy director (general dept.) — P. Makhno, * Academic secretary — L. Drofan’, PhD, ast prof. * Head of publication dept. — I. Kulinsky, * Head of art-tech. dept. — O. Chervinsky.<ref>http://www.mari.kiev.ua/03.htm</ref>
== Projects ==
[[File:MODERN ART RESEARCH INSTITUTE gallery.jpg|thumb|left|350px|Modern Art Research Institute]]
* 50th and 52nd [[Venice Biennale]]s (Italy; V. Sydorenko, curators: A. Soloviev, A. Fedoruk), * «East neighbours» ([[Utrecht (city)|Utrecht]], Netherlands), * «Authentification» (Paris, France), * «[[Gogolfest]]» (curator [[Anton Solomoukha|A. Solomoukha]]), * «Art-Kiev» (curator A. Solomoukha), * «Gurzuf seasons» (curator О. Avramenko), * «Kiev - Paris», * «International festival of social culture», «The newest directions» (Ukraine). * «Quicker than history», [[Kiasma|Museum of Modern Art KIASMA]] ([[Finland]]), * «Blood - the lines and connections», Museum of Modern Art of Denver (United States), * «Travers Video» 10th International festival of installation and video, [[Toulouse]] (France), * «Now», 5th International Art festival, Magdeburg (Germany).
=== Films ===
* «Nikolay VIngranovsky» (director Marina Kondratieva), * «Once I woke up» (director Marina Kondratieva), * «Real master class» (director Oksana Chepelik).
== Publications ==
=== Collective monographies === * «Essays about the history of cinematography of Ukraine», * «Essays about the history of theatrical art of Ukraine XХ century», * «Essays about the history of fine art of Ukraine ХХ century: 2 vol.»
=== Periodicals ===
* Since 1998 - «Art criticism of Ukraine», * Since 1999 - «Art horizons», * Since 2003 - «Art, history, modernity, theory», * Since 2004 - «Modern Art», * Since 2004 - «Contemporary problems of research, restoration and cultural heritage preservations», * Since 2004 - «Art culture. Actual problems», * Since 2005 - «Contemporary problems of art-education in Ukraine», * 2008–2011 - Illustrated magazine «Art-Italics» (Арт-Курсив).
== Partners ==
* «Fondation of Tereshenko» (Kiev), * The ministry of culture and tourism of Ukraine, * Ukrainian Academy of Arts (Kiev), * Национальная академия изобразительного искусства и архитектуры (Киев), * Stichting Cultural Aid (Netherlands).
== See also ==
* [[Ukrainian Academy of Arts]]
== References == <references/>
== External links == * [http://www.mari.kiev.ua/index.html Official '''Modern Art Research Institute of Ukrainian Academy of Arts''' website]

revision.comment: Changing [[Wikipedia:Short description|short description]] from "Works decorated with arrangements of porcupine quills or feathers" to "Works decorated with overlays of porcupine quills or feathers" ([[User:Galobtter/Shortdesc helper|Shortdesc helper]])
revision.text:
{{short description|Works decorated with overlays of porcupine quills or feathers}} [[File:Huron Moccasin.png|thumb|220px|[[Wyandot people|Huron]] quillwork moccasin]] '''Quillwork''' is a form of [[textile]] embellishment traditionally practiced by [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Native Americans]] that employs the [[quill]]s of [[porcupine]]s as an aesthetic element. Quills from bird feathers were also occasionally used in quillwork.
==History== [[File:Upper MO quillwork pre1804 UPenn.jpg|thumb|Backside of loomed quillwork collected from an [[Plains Indians|Upper Missouri tribe]] by the [[Lewis and Clark Expedition]], pre-1804. All [[natural dyes]]. Collection of the [[University of Pennsylvania Museum]]]] Porcupine quillwork is an art form completely unique to North America. Before the introduction of glass beads, quillwork was a major decorative element used by the peoples who resided in the porcupine's natural habitat,<ref name="worldtex">Gillow and Sentance 223</ref> which included [[indigenous peoples of the Subarctic]], [[indigenous peoples of the Northeastern Woodlands|Northeastern Woodlands]], and [[Northern Plains]]. The use of quills in designs spans from [[Maine]] to [[Alaska]].<ref name="Orchard">Orchard</ref> Quillworking tools were discovered in [[Alberta, Canada]] and date back to the 6th century CE.<ref>Dubin 265</ref>
[[Cheyenne]] [[oral history]], as told by Picking Bones Woman to George Bird Grinnell, says quilling came to their tribe from a man who married a woman, who hid her true identity as a buffalo. His son was also a buffalo. The man visited his wife and son in their buffalo home, and, while among the buffalo, the man learned the art of quilling, which he shared with the women of his tribe.<ref name="Penney and Horse Capture, 119">Penney and Horse Capture 119</ref>
Joining the Cheyenne Quilling Society was a prestigious honor for Cheyenne women. Upon entering the Society, women would work first on quilling [[Moccasin (footwear)|moccasins]], then [[cradle board|cradleboards]], rosettes for men's shirts and [[tipi]]s, and ultimately, hide robes and backrests.<ref name="Penney and Horse Capture, 119"/>
Porcupine quills often adorned [[rawhide (textile)|rawhide]] and tanned hides, but during the 19th century, [[Wiigwaasi-makak|quilled birch bark boxes]] were a popular trade item to sell to European-Americans among Eastern and Great Lakes tribes. Quillwork was used to create and decorate a variety of Native American items, including those of daily usage to Native American men and women. These include clothing such as coats and moccasins, accessories such as bags and belts, and furniture attachments such as a cradle cover.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Cole|first=Christina|last2=Herald|first2=Susan|year=2010|title=The History and Analysis of Pre-Aniline Native American Quillwork Dyes|url=http://digitalcommons.unl.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1013&context=tsaconf|journal=Textile Society of America Symposium Proceedings|volume=|pages=|via=Digital Commons@University of Nebraska-Lincoln}}</ref>
==Technique== [[Image:Quill knife sheath.png|thumb|left|140px|A quillwork knife sheath.]] Quills suitable for embellishment are two to three inches long and may be dyed before use.<ref name="worldtex" /> In their natural state, the quills are pale yellow to white with black tips. The tips are usually snipped off before use. Quills readily take dye, which originally was derived from local plants and included a wide spectrum of colors, with black, yellow, and red being the most common. By the 19th century, aniline dyes were available through trade and made dying easier.<ref>Feest 138</ref>
The quills can be flattened with specific bone tools or by being run through one's teeth. Awls were used to punch holes in hides, and [[sinew]], later replaced by European thread, was used to bind the quills to the hides.
The four most common techniques for quillwork are [[Applique|appliqué]], [[embroidery]], wrapping, and [[loom]] weaving.<ref>Feest 215</ref> Appliquéd quills are stitched into hide in a manner that covers the stitches.<ref name="worldtex" /> In wrapping, a single quill may be wrapped upon itself or two quills may be intertwined.<ref name="worldtex" />
Quills can be appliquéd singly to form curvilinear patterns, as found on [[Odawa people|Odawa]] pouches from the 18th century.<ref>Vincent 15</ref> This technique lends itself to floral designs popularized among [[indigenous peoples of the Northeastern Woodlands|northeastern tribes]] by [[Ursulines|Ursuline nuns.]] [[Wyandot people|Huron]] women excelled at floral quillwork during the 18th and 19th centuries.<ref>Vincent 24</ref>
[[Plains Indians|Plains]] quillwork is characterized by bands of rectangles creating geometrical patterns found also in Plains painting.<ref>Feest 140</ref> Rosettes of concentric circles of quillwork commonly adorned historical Plains men's shirts, as did parallel panels of quillwork on the sleeves. These highly abstracted designs had layers of symbolic meaning.
The [[Pembina Band of Chippewa Indians|Red River Ojibwe]] of [[Manitoba]] created crisp, geometric patterns by weaving quills on a loom in the 19th century.<ref>Vincent 28 and 43</ref>
==Today== [[File:Ferdy's dragonfly.jpg|thumb|left|Contemporary quillwork design on [[birch bark]], by Ferdy Goode]]
Quillwork never died out as a living art form in the Northern Plains. Some communities that had lost their quillwork tradition have been able to revive the art form. For instance, no women quilled in the [[Dene]] community of [[Wha Ti, Northwest Territories]] by the late 1990s. The Dene Cultural Institute held two workshops there in 1999 and 2000, effectively reviving quillwork in Wha Ti.<ref>Marie and Thompson, 29</ref>
The art form is very much alive today. Examples of contemporary, award-winning quillworkers include [[Juanita Growing Thunder Fogarty]], ([[Sioux]]-[[Assiniboine people|Assiniboine]]) artist;<ref>Durbin 279 and 304</ref> Dorothy Brave Eagle ([[Oglala Lakota]]) of [[Denver, Colorado]];<ref>Melmer, David. "Quillwork: Lakota Style." ''Indian Country Today.'' 22 Sept 2004.</ref> Kanatiiosh ([[Akwesasne|Akwesasne Mohawk]]) of [[St. Regis Mohawk Reservation]];<ref>[http://www.native-languages.org/quillwork.htm Native American Quillwork.] ''Native Languages of the Americans.'' 2008 (retrieved 19 Feb 2009)</ref><ref>Roberts, Kathaleen. [http://santafe.com/Pages/2017 Native Costume.] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716004937/http://santafe.com/Pages/2017 |date=July 16, 2011 }} ''Journal Santa Fe.'' 3 Nov 2008. Retrieved 19 Feb 2009.</ref> [[Sarah Hardisty]] ([[Dene]]) of [[Jean Marie River]], Northwest Territories;<ref>{{cite web|last1=Menicoche|first1=Kevin A.|title=Kevin A. Menicoche on Condolences On The Passing Of Nahendeh Resident Sarah Hardisty|url=http://hansard.opennwt.ca/debates/2014/3/3/kevin-a-menicoche-1/only/|publisher=OpenNWT|date=March 3, 2014}}</ref> Leonda Fast Buffalo Horse ([[Piegan Blackfeet|Blackfeet]]) of [[Browning, Montana]];<ref>[http://art.mt.gov/folklife/folklife_fast.asp Leonda Fast Buffalo Horse: Quillwork.] ''Montana Arts Council.'' (retrieved 19 Feb 2009)</ref> and Deborah Magee Sherer ([[Piegan Blackfeet|Blackfeet]]) of [[Cut Bank, Montana]].<ref>Horse Capture 118-119</ref>
[[Northern Lakes College]] of [[Alberta, Canada]] teaches a college-level course in quillwork art.
==See also== *[[Hair drop]], men's ornaments typically featuring quillwork
==Notes== {{reflist|33em}}
==References== *Dubin, Lois Sherr. ''North American Indian Jewelry and Adornment: From Prehistory to the Present''. New York: Harry N. Abrams, Inc. Publishers, 1999. {{ISBN|0-8109-3689-5}}. *Feest, Christian F. ''Native Arts of North America''. London: Thames and Hudson, 1992. {{ISBN|978-0-500-20262-3}}. *Gillow, John and Bryan Sentance (1999). ''World Textiles: A Visual Guide to Traditional Techniques''. Thames & Hudson. {{ISBN|978-0-500-28247-2}}. *Horse Capture, John D. et al. ''Beauty, Honor, and Tradition: The Legacy of Plains Indian Shirts''. Washington DC: National Museum of the American Indian, 2001. {{ISBN|978-0-8166-3947-2}}. *Marie, Suzan and Judy Thompson. "Whadoo Themi: Long-Ago People's Packsack: Dene Babiche Bags: Tradition and Revival." ''Canadian Museum of Civilization Mercury Series''. Ethnology Paper 141. 2004: 29 *Orchard, William C. (1916). ''The Technique of Porcupine-Quill Decoration Among The North American Indians''. The Museum of the American Indian Heye Foundation. {{ISBN|978-0-943604-00-8}}. *Penney, David W. and George Horse Capture. ''North American Indian Art''. London: Thames & Hudson, 2004. {{ISBN|978-0-500-20377-4}}. *Vincent, Gilbert T. ''Masterpieces of American Indian Art from the Eugene and Clare Thaw Collection''. New York: Harry N. Abrams, 1995. {{ISBN|978-0-8109-2628-8}}.
==External links== {{commons category}} * [http://www.nmai.si.edu/searchcollections/results.aspx?catids=0&objmat=Quills&src=1-4 Porcupine and bird quillwork], in the collection of the [[National Museum of the American Indian]] *[http://www.nativetech.org/quill/index.php Substantial material about quillwork from nativetech.org]
{{beadwork}} {{embroidery}}

revision.text:
[[Image:Batik Indonesia.jpg|right|thumb|200px|Indonesian batik fabric]]
'''Resist dyeing''' ('''resist-dyeing''') is a traditional method of [[dyeing]] [[textile]]s with patterns. Methods are used to "[[resist]]" or prevent the dye from reaching all the cloth, thereby creating a pattern and ground. The most common forms use [[wax]], some type of paste made from starch or mud,<ref name="BGAfrica">{{cite web|title=Batik in Africa |url=http://www.batikguild.org.uk/historyAfrica.asp | publisher=The Batik Guild| accessdate=April 29, 2014 }}</ref> or a mechanical resist that manipulates the cloth such as tying or stitching. Another form of resist involves using a chemical agent in a specific type of dye that will repel another type of dye [[textile printing|printed]] over the top. The best-known varieties today include [[tie-dye]] and [[batik]].
==Basic methods== '''Wax or paste''': melted [[wax]] or some form of paste is applied to cloth before being dipped in dye. Wherever the wax has seeped through the fabric, the dye will not penetrate. Sometimes several colors are used, with a series of dyeing, drying and waxing steps. The wax may also be applied to another piece of cloth to make a [[stencil]], which is then placed over the cloth, and dye applied to the assembly; this is known as '''resist printing'''.
'''Stencils''': a [[stencil]] is placed over the fabric where it is to be shielded from ink, similar to how [[screenprinting|screen prints]] are made.
'''Mechanical''': the cloth is tied, stitched, or clamped using clothespegs or wooden blocks to shield areas of the fabric.
'''Chemical''': a modern textile printing method, commonly achieved using two different classes of fiber [[reactive dyes]], one of which must be of the vinyl sulfone type. A chemical-resisting agent is combined with dye Type A, and printed using the [[screenprint]] method and allowed to dry. A second dye, Type B, is then printed overtop. The resist agent in Type A chemically prevents Type B from reacting with the fabric, resulting in a crisp pattern/ground relationship.<ref name="chemicalresist">{{cite web |title = Vinyl Sulfone Fiber Reactive Dyes: Using Remazol Dyes for Chemical Resist Dyeing |url=http://www.pburch.net/dyeing/remazol.shtml#chemicalresist |publisher=All About Hand Dyeing |date=September 30, 2011 |accessdate = April 13, 2016}} </ref>
==History== Resist dyeing has been very widely used in Eurasia and Africa since ancient times. The first discoveries of pieces of linen was from Egypt and date from the fourth century. Cloth, used for mummy wrappings, was coated with wax, scratched with a sharp stylus, and dyed with a mixture of blood and ashes. After dyeing the cloth was washed in hot water to remove the wax. In Asia, this technique was practiced in China during the T'ang dynasty (618–907), in India and Japan in the Nara period (645–794). In Africa it was originally practiced by the Yoruba tribe in Nigeria, Soninke and Wolof in Senegal.<ref name="BGAfrica"/>
==Traditions using wax or paste== * [[Guizhou|Guizhou Province]] of China had a strong tradition of wax dyeing
[[Image:Roketsuzome printing wheels.jpg|thumb|200px|Rōketsuzome printing wheels at Roketsuzome Yamamoto, [[Kyoto]].]] * [[Indonesia]], [[Malaysia]] and [[India]] – [[Batik]] with wax * [[Japan]] – [[Rōketsuzome]] with wax, [[Katazome]], Yūzen and [[Tsutsugaki]] with rice-paste * [[Africa]] – Yoruba people of [[Nigeria]] uses cassava paste as a resist while the people of [[Senegal]] use rice paste. Among other terms, [[Madiba shirt|Madiba]].<ref name="BGAfrica"/>
==Traditions using tying or stitching== * [[Indonesia]] and [[Malaysia]] – [[Ikat]], where only the [[warp (weaving)|warp]] or [[weft]] is dyed (article covers similar techniques elsewhere). * [[India]] * Africa – [[Adire (textile art)|Adire]] * Modern West – [[Tie-dye]] * Japan – [[Shibori]]
==Traditions using printing== * [[Japan]]- [[Katazome|Katagami]] and [[Bingata]] with stencils * [[China]] – about 500 AD the ''jia xie'' method for dyeing (usually silk) using wood blocks was invented. An upper and a lower block is made, with carved out compartments opening to the back, fitted with plugs. The cloth, usually folded a number of times, is inserted and clamped between the two blocks. By unplugging the different compartments and filling them with dyes of different colours, a multi-coloured pattern can be printed over quite a large area of folded cloth.<ref name="cave">Shelagh Vainker in Anne Farrer (ed), "Caves of the Thousand Buddhas" , 1990, British Museum publications, {{ISBN|0-7141-1447-2}}</ref>
==Other traditions== [[Image:UkiePysanky2006.jpg|thumb|A mix of modern and traditional Ukrainian [[pysanky]]]] * [[Ukraine]], [[Russia]] and [[Poland]] – [[Pysanka]], with wax for eggs at [[Easter]]
==See also== *[[Woodblock printing]] *[[Byzantine dress]]
==References== <references/>
{{Dyeing}}
[[Category:Textile arts]]

{{Infobox person | image = Sally-Cruikshank-1970s.jpg | caption = Sally Cruikshank at Snazelle Films in the 1970s, where she produced her signature "Quasi" animated shorts | birth_date = {{birth-date and age|June 1949}} | birth_place = [[Chatham, New Jersey|Chatham]], [[New Jersey]], U.S. | birth_name = Sarah Cruikshank | spouse = [[Kim Deitch]] (1971–c. 1982; common-law)
Jon Davison (1984–present) | children = Dinah | occupation = [[Animator]] | networth = | years_active = 1971–present }} '''Sarah "Sally" Cruikshank'''{{cite web |url=http://funonmars.blogspot.com/2008/09/hating-sarah.html |title=Hating Sarah |publisher=Sally Cruikshank's official blog |date=September 9, 2008 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5xAneY3Wd?url=http://funonmars.blogspot.com/2008/09/hating-sarah.html |archivedate=March 14, 2011 |deadurl=no |df= }} (born June 1949)Dixon, Wheeler Winston. ''The Second Century of Cinema: The Past and Future of the Moving Image'' ([[State University of New York]] Press, 2000), p. 236. {{ISBN|978-0-7914-4516-7}}. Cruikshank: " Well, I was born in New Jersey in 1949." is an American [[cartoonist]] and [[animator]] whose work includes animation for the [[Sesame Workshop|Children's Television Workshop]] program ''[[Sesame Street]]'', and whose short "[[Quasi at the Quackadero]]" (1975) was inducted into the United States [[National Film Registry]]. ==Biography== ===Early life and education=== Sally Cruikshank was born in [[Chatham, New Jersey|Chatham]], [[New Jersey]], the daughter of parents Rose and Ernest.[http://funonmars.blogspot.com/2008/12/more-party.html "More Party"], Cruikshank blog, December 29, 2008 Her parents were both [[Southern United States|Southerners]], with her father, an [[accountant]] who worked in nearby [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]], holding a [[Phi Beta Kappa]] key from [[Duke University]], in [[North Carolina]]. Ernest's mother had been the president of the boarding school formerly known as [[Saint Mary's School (Raleigh, North Carolina)|St. Mary's College]] in that state.Dixon, Wheeler Winston, ed. ''Collected Interviews: Voices from Twentieth-Century Cinema.'' [[Carbondale, Illinois|Carbondale]], [[Illinois]] : Southern Illinois University Press, 2001, p. 208. {{ISBN|0-8093-2417-2}} Cruikshank has a brother,[http://funonmars.blogspot.com/2009/11/10-little-indians.html "10 Little Indians"], Cruikshank blog, November 28, 2009 and had a sister, Carol,[http://funonmars.blogspot.com/2008/11/july-17-1958-from-carol.html "July 17, 1958 from Carol"], Cruikshank blog, November 11, 2008 who died in 1991.[http://funonmars.blogspot.com/2008/12/out-of-here.html "Out of here"], Cruikshank blog, December 05, 2008 Their maternal aunt, Bea, was a painter from the 1910s to the 1940s, whose work included a portrait commission by [[US President]] [[Franklin Delano Roosevelt]].[http://funonmars.blogspot.com/2008/09/auntie-beas-portrait-of-my-sister.html "Auntie Bea's portrait of my sister"] at Cruikshank blog, September 10, 2008 Cruikshank studied art at [[Smith College]],Counts, Kyle. "The Short Life of Sally Cruikshank", ''Starlog Presents Comics Scene'' #7, January 1982, p. 40 where in her junior year art teacher [[Elliot Offner]] sent slides of her colored-pencil and clay-relief-on-paper drawings to a screening committee that resulted in a scholarship to the two-month [[Yale University|Yale]] Summer Art School. At the urging of a classmate there, Warner Wada, she began considering adapting her drawing style to animation.Counts, pp. 40–41 Returning to Smith for her senior year and obtaining the primer ''Animation'' by [[Preston Blair]], Cruikshank, with additional research, arranged for a special-studies class in animation. With an animation stand consisting of a [[Bolex]] camera attached to a photo enlarger, constructed by instructor David Batchelder, she produced her first [[animated short]], the three-minute, [[16mm]] "Ducky". Done with [[watercolor]] and paper animation, it starred a prototype versionCounts, p. 41 of her future recurring character Quasi, which one writer characterized as "an infantile duck with buck front teeth, thick glasses and a red cape".Counts, p. 43 Cruikshank, describing her [[anthropomorphic]] characters, said, "My ducks are based on the ducks from [[Carl Barks]]' comics. But I guess they got twisted in memory, because people don't seem to see much similarity between them." Encouraged by the response of "Ducky", Cruikshank, after graduation, enrolled at the [[San Francisco Art Institute]], in [[San Francisco]], [[California]], to study filmmaking. Under instructor [[Larry Jordan]], she made the five-minute animated short "Fun on Mars" (1971), which used watercolor, [[crayon]] markers on paper, [[Cutout animation|cutouts]], and [[collage]]. Produced for $100, it also featured early versions of her trademark duck-creatures. Her next short, "Chow Fun" (1972), created with a $400 grant secured in association with [[PBS]], mixed paper animation and cutouts glued onto [[animation cel]]s. ==="Quasi at the Quackadero"=== While editing "Chow Fun" at San Francisco's Snazelle Films, a [[Sponsored film|commercial-film]] company that also rented out space and film equipment, Cruikshank, at an employee's suggestion, showed her work to company president E. E. Gregg Snazelle, who gave her a job a week later "to experiment in animation and do [[TV commercial]]s when there was work".Counts, pp. 41-42 By the end of summer 1972, Cruikshank was head animator there.Counts, p. 42 In 2009, she recalled of her time with Snazelle, {{quote|The job was to experiment with animation, and do commercials for him when the jobs came in. He also hoped I'd figure out how to solve [[3-D film|3-d]] without glasses. Needless to say I didn't solve 3-d. I didn't even do very many commercials over ten years, but I showed up at 8:30, took an hour off for lunch and worked till 5:30. I was paid $350 a month, and I could live on that then. He encouraged me generously without ever paying much attention to me. These days if an opportunity like that even existed, you'd be forced to sign all kinds of rights statements for characters and content created, but this was before ''[[Star Wars]]'' and he just seemed to be happy to have me around. We were never particularly close. It spoiled me for any job after that. I made all my 'Quasi' films while I was working at Snazelle.[http://funonmars.blogspot.com/search?updated-max=2010-02-17T17%3A36%3A00-07%3A00&max-results=20 "Quasi's Big Day"], Cruikshank blog, December 30, 2009}} [[File:Quasi at the Quackadero (1975) sample frame.jpg|thumb|300px|Still from 6:49 of Cruikshank's signature work, "[[Quasi at the Quackadero]]", depicting Anita and Quasi at left.]] In 1975 Cruikshank made a comic strip based on her characters Anita and Quasi, which was published in the third issue of the underground comics magazine [[Arcade (comics magazine)|Arcade]]. https://www.lambiek.net/artists/c/cruikshank_sally.htm At Snazelle, Cruikshank began developing her best-known work, "[[Quasi at the Quackadero]]" (1975), [[working title]]s of which included "I Walked with a Duck", "Hold That Quasi", and "Quasi Quacks Up". The 10-minute, [[35mm]] short, with 100 watercolor backgrounds and approximately 5,000 cels, took two years for Cruikshank to draw, followed by four months for photography and [[post-production]]. Cruikshank independently financedCounts, p. 44 the $6,000 budget, which went primarily for cel painting, [[sound recording]] and lab and camera work. [[Underground comix|Underground cartoonist]] [[Kim Deitch]], then Cruikshank's boyfriend, did much of the [[inker|inking]], using dip pen and [[rapidograph]], with Kathryn Lenihan doing most of the cel painting. The short starred Quasi, voiced by Deitch; Anita, which one writer described as "[[Betty Boop]] with a [[New wave music|New Wave]] wardrobe" and whose [[Mae West]]-like voice was supplied by Cruikshank; and robot Rollo. They progress through the Quackadero, a [[Coney Island]]-esque sideshow with such attractions as the Hall of Time Mirrors, which depict the viewer as he or she will look in "old age" or "100 years from now", and the Time Holes, in which one can lean on a railing and see a live slice of three million years [[Before Christ|B.C.]] unfold.Counts, p. 43-44 The music, by the [[Berkeley, California]] band the [[R. Crumb & His Cheap Suit Serenaders|Cheap Suit Serenaders]], used slide flute, xylophone, ukulele, duck call, boat whistle and bagpipe to create what Cruikshank called the "strange, gallopy feeling" of 1920s/1930s dance-band music, of which she is a devotee.Counts, p. 45 "Quasi at the Quackadero" won awards and was shown at the [[Filmex|Los Angeles Film Exposition]], and made its first theatrical booking at the Northside Theater in Berkeley, not far from Cruikshank's home at the time at 1890 Arch Street in that city.[http://funonmars.blogspot.com/2009/12/letter-from-jan-18-1981.html "A letter from Jan. 18, 1981"], Cruikshank blog, December 23, 2009 ===Other early projects=== Cruikshank's next short, the eight-minute, 35mm "Make Me Psychic" (1978; working title "Mesmeroid Madness") returns Quasi and Anita and adds the suave Snozzy. Built around a device that taps into one's latent telekinetic power, leading to [[slapstick]] at a party, the $14,000 film also was financed by Cruikshank, with the higher budget going toward the hiring of additional cel painters and increased lab fees. Of its slicker look than her previous short, Cruikshank said, "People didn't know what to make of 'Quasi.' It was pretty hard to absorb in one sitting, solid. So, I thought I would try directing the eye more, by simplifying things and giving the next film a clearer focus." The Cheap Suit Serenaders again supplied music. In 1980, Cruikshank won a $10,000 grant from the [[National Endowment for the Arts]] to create a [[storyboard]] and three-minute sample reel for a proposed [[animated feature]], ''Quasi's Cabaret'', which she described as involving "three hedonistic ducks who try to open the ultimate tropical nightclub." She also tried developing feature projects combining live action and animation, one a comedy set in a [[mental institution]], the other, ''Joystick'', "sort of a humorous horror story" about the effects of computer animation on an artist modeled on herself. Additionally, she attempted to sell [[Cable television in the United States#Programming|cable-TV network]]s on "Weird Airways", a projected series of three-minute shorts starring Snozzy as the owner-pilot of a [[charter airline]] and Anita as a [[flight attendant]]. ===Later work and life=== Cruikshank evolved a recognizable style with [[Surrealism|surrealistic]] and [[Psychedelia|psychedelic]] elements. Her film "Face Like a Frog" (1987) bears a musical score by [[Oingo Boingo]], with the group's [[Danny Elfman]] singing his song "Don't Go in the Basement."[http://www.funonmars.com/portfolio.html Portfolio: "Face Like a Frog"] at Fun on Mars (official site) Cruikshank has contributed [[animation]] sequences to [[feature films]], including ''[[Twilight Zone: The Movie]]'' (1983) and ''[[Top Secret!]]'' (1984), as well as the opening [[title sequence]]s to ''[[Ruthless People]]'' (1986), ''[[Mannequin (1987 film)|Mannequin]]'' (1987), ''[[Loverboy (1989 film)|Loverboy]]'' (1989), ''[[Madhouse (1990 film)|Madhouse]]'' (1990), and ''[[Smiley Face (film)|Smiley Face]]'' (2007).[http://funonmars.blogspot.com/2009/03/smiley-face-titles.html "Smiley Face Titles"], Cruikshank blog, March 30, 2009 She has also worked in commercials and [[Web site|website]] design. Cruikshank also animated and produced many music videos for ''[[Sesame Street]]'' from 1989-1999.[http://www.funonmars.com/resume.html Resume] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110711054918/http://www.funonmars.com/resume.html |date=2011-07-11 }} at Fun on Mars (official site) For a short time in the 1990s, Cruikshank was employed by the Palo Alto laboratory and technology incubator [[Interval Research Corporation]] as an animator.{{cite web|last= Landekic|first=Lola|title=Sally Cruikshank: A Career Retrospective, Part 2|url=http://www.artofthetitle.com/feature/sally-cruikshank-a-career-retrospective-part-two/|publisher=ArtOfTheTitle.com| date=May 27, 2015 |accessdate=June 23, 2015| archivedate= June 23, 2015| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20150623020115/http://www.artofthetitle.com/feature/sally-cruikshank-a-career-retrospective-part-two/ | deadurl=no}} Cruikshank is in the process, as of 2011, of transferring her works into 35mm film format, for archival purposes,[http://funonmars.blogspot.com/2011/11/obsolete-formats.html "Obsolete Formats"], Cruikshank blog, November 29, 2011 In October 2012, several 35mm prints of her work were screened at the [[Museum of Modern Art]].{{citation needed|date=December 2012}} ==Personal life== Cruikshank was in a decade-long [[common-law marriage]] with [[Underground comix|underground cartoonist]] [[Kim Deitch]] during the period 1971–c. 1982.Deitch, Kim. [http://www.tcj.com/part-10-cartoon-tunes/ "Mad About Music: My Life in Records: Part 10: Cartoon Tunes,"] ''The Comics Journal'' (SEP. 9, 2011).Murphyao, Amanda, in {{cite book| url = https://books.google.com/books?id=hnuQBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA548&lpg=PA548&dq=gene+deitch+kim+simon&source=bl&ots=G4VvqCmh4V&sig=aKIlOLeYpfHYcbUN-wo8wrcrcsY&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CDIQ6AEwA2oVChMIvOyN7vj6yAIVzDY-Ch2Qkgga#v=onepage&q=gene%20deitch%20kim%20simon&f=false | title=Comics through Time: A History of Icons, Idols, and Ideas | chapter=Deitch, Kim (1944- ) | first=M. Keith, ed.|last= Booker| publisher=Greenwood |year=2014 | isbn = 978-0313397509}} On March 17, 1984,[http://funonmars.blogspot.com/2009/03/march-17-good.html "March 17 the Good"], Cruikshank blog, March 18, 2009 she married producer [[Jon Davison (film producer)|Jon Davison]],Dixon, ''Collected Interviews'', p.209 with whom she has a daughter, Dinah.[http://funonmars.blogspot.com/2010/02/10-days-or-so.html "10 days or so!"], Cruikshank blog, February 08, 2010 ==Influences and style== Cruikshank prefers the early [[New York City]] animation of such producers as the [[Fleischer Studios]] and the [[Van Beuren Studios]], as well as early [[Bob Clampett]]. In a 1981 interview, she said of her own style at the time, {{quote|I think I have a different concept of motion than most other animators. One thing that bothers me about so many contemporary animators is that they've learned a language from other animators. You see the same hand movements, the same 'blink' 'blink' 'blink' when a character asks a question. Too many animators don't try to picture the dynamics of movement, to use it creatively. I'm not that great an animator per se, but I do think I have a sense of motion that makes for an offbeat view of the world.}} ==Animated short films== * "Ducky" (1971) * "Fun on Mars" (1971) * "Chow Fun" (1972) * "[[Quasi at the Quackadero]]" (1975) * "Make Me Psychic" (1978) * "Quasi's Cabaret Trailer" (1980) * "Face Like a Frog" (1987) Several other short films are on Cruikshank's [[YouTube]] channel. ==Awards and honors== In 1986, Cruikshank won the initial [[Maya Deren Award]] for independent film and video artists, given by the [[American Film Institute]], along with [[Stan Brakhage]] and [[Nam June Paik]].{{cite news | url = http://articles.latimes.com/1986-02-01/entertainment/ca-3164_1_independent-film | title = AFI Gives 1st Award For Independent Film Makers | date = February 1, 1986 | last = Taylor | first = Clarke | work = [[Los Angeles Times]] | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/6CTliWCu5?url=http://articles.latimes.com/1986-02-01/entertainment/ca-3164_1_independent-film | archivedate = November 27, 2012 | deadurl = no | df = }} In 2009, "[[Quasi at the Quackadero]]" was selected for preservation in the United States [[National Film Registry]] by the [[Library of Congress]].{{cite press release | url = https://www.loc.gov/today/pr/2009/09-250.html | title = Michael Jackson, the Muppets and Early Cinema Tapped for Preservation in 2009 Library of Congress National Film Registry | publisher = [[Library of Congress]] | date = December 30, 2009 | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/5xAnnCKKS?url=http://www.loc.gov/today/pr/2009/09-250.html | archivedate = March 14, 2011 | deadurl = no | df = }} It was voted {{Numero|46}} in the 1994 book ''[[The 50 Greatest Cartoons]]: As Selected by 1,000 Animation Professionals''.{{cite book|authorlink=Jerry Beck|first=Jerry, ed.|last=Beck|location=[[Atlanta, Georgia]]|publisher=Turner Publishing|year= 1994|isbn= 1-878685-49-X | title =[[The 50 Greatest Cartoons]]: As Selected by 1,000 Animation Professionals}} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== *{{youtube|user=laughingsal}} *{{IMDb name|id=0190012|name=Sally Cruikshank}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070806082528/http://www.awn.com/cruikshank/ AWN.com: Sally Cruikshank gallery] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Cruikshank, Sally}} [[Category:1949 births]] [[Category:Animators from New Jersey]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American animators]] [[Category:American experimental filmmakers]] [[Category:American female comics artists]] alumni]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2015}} {{Use Australian English|date=July 2015}} {{BLP sources|date=May 2014}}
'''Shayne Greenman''' (born 11 January 1969 in Benalla,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.benalla.vic.gov.au/|title=Benalla Rural City Home Page|publisher=|accessdate=16 December 2014}}</ref> Victoria, Australia) is an award winning Australian artisan baker, sugar craftsman and [[culinary art]]ist.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://shaynegreenman.com/|title=Shayne Greenman|work=Shayne Greenman|accessdate=16 December 2014}}</ref>
In early 2012, Greenman became the gold medallist in the Australian Artisan Baking Cup<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hospitalitymagazine.com.au/food/news/australia-s-best-compete-in-international-baking-c|title=Australia's best compete in international baking cup|work=Hospitality|accessdate=16 December 2014}}</ref> and was the World Championship Artisan baker at the SIGEP Baking Cup in Rimini, Italy.<ref>http://en.sigep.it/</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.seekingmedia.com.au/news.php?newsid=2394|title=Aussie Artisans Bake World Competition|publisher=|accessdate=16 December 2014}}</ref> In late 2012 he won the Australian Culinary Challenge Decorated Cake Award,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.austculinary.com.au/chapters/victoria/366-australian-culinary-challenge-2012 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-07-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714195233/http://www.austculinary.com.au/chapters/victoria/366-australian-culinary-challenge-2012 |archivedate=14 July 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Greenman placed Top 5 in the International Baking Association Cup in Munich,Germany <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iba.de/en/home/|title=iba - The world's leading trade fair for bakery, confectionery and snacks|publisher=|accessdate=16 December 2014}}</ref> Greenman recently visited as a guest at the Ecole Gastonomique Bellouet Conseil, Le Cordon Bleu Culinary Institute and L’Atelier Des Sens in Paris, France.
Greenman competed at the 2014 [[Cake decorating|Cake Decorating]] Championships held in Sydney Olympic Park. at the Cake, Bake and Sweets Show<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cakebakeandsweets.com/sydney/|title=Cake Bake & Sweets Show Sydney|work=Cake Bake & Sweets Show Sydney|accessdate=16 December 2014}}</ref> and won two first prizes in Masters Division, one for a sugarcraft piece depicting the birth of a dragonfly and another Novelty cake depicting a 1920s fortune teller a life size bust sculpted out of cake and was a finalist in a third category Masters Wedding cake section depicting a spring pond with two sculpted white swans entwined around a nest of hatching eggs surrounded with bull rushes water lilies and water iris.
In September 2014 Greenman travelled to the U.S to be an International guest demonstrator at the 21st Birthday celebrations of Oklahoma State Sugar Art Show<ref>{{cite web|url=http://oklahomasugarartists.com/presenters/|title=Presenters - Welcome to OklahomaSugarArtists.com|publisher=|accessdate=16 December 2014}}</ref> created by [[Kerry Vincent]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kerryvincent.com/bio.html|title=KerryVincent.com: Bio|publisher=|accessdate=16 December 2014}}</ref> His Grand National Wedding Cake Competition entry which was completed in under four days won him a Silver Medal Placement along with the other finalists in the competition.
== References == {{reflist|2}} * Paul, M (2012). "Pastry chef rises to occasion", ABC News. * Lewis, C (2012). "Battling Bakers Go Dough to Dough", The Australian. * Vincent, K (2014). "Celebrity Presenters at 2014 Oklahoma State Sugar Art Show"
{{DEFAULTSORT:Greenman, Shayne}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Bakers]] [[Category:Pastry chefs]] [[Category:Culinary arts]] [[Category:Australian television chefs]] [[Category:1969 births]]

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=March 2007}}
'''Spex''' is a form of amateur [[comedy]] theatre act performed by university students in [[Sweden]] and parts of [[Finland]]. University cities, such as [[Gothenburg]], [[Lund]], [[Uppsala]], and [[Linköping]] have long-running traditions of spex. The word is likely derived from abbreviated student slang for ''spektakel'' (spectacle; scene; show).<ref name="linkop">{{cite web|website=Linkopings Student Spex|title=Spex in English|accessdate=2 May 2017|url=https://www.studentspex.se/spex-in-english/}}</ref><ref>[http://g3.spraakdata.gu.se/saob/show.phtml?filenr=2/16/69540.html ''Svenska Akademins Ordbok'' entry: ''Spex''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110525130504/http://g3.spraakdata.gu.se/saob/show.phtml?filenr=2%2F16%2F69540.html |date=May 25, 2011 }}</ref> This form of comedy theatre may also be known as '''Gyckel''' (buffoonery), when performed at a [[Gask]].
==History== The first spexes were performed possibly as early as the 16th century in [[Uppsala]]. Local students were practising Latin by writing short plays in Latin, called spexes. These performances were performed by male-only casts, as all the students at that time were male,<ref name="linkop"/><ref name="holger"/> and the tradition of gender switching for roles continues today.<ref name="holger"/> Over the next 300 years the spexes developed into their modern form, which emerged around 1850 at [[Uppsala University]].<ref name="holger">{{cite web|url=https://www.holgerspexet.se/info/english|website=Holger Spexet|accessdate=2 May 2017|title=What is Spex?}}</ref>
The first spexes in Finland were performed at the [[Helsinki University of Technology]] at the beginning of the 20th century.<ref>[http://www.teekkarispeksi.fi/speksi/historia "The History page of Teekkarispeksi" entry: ''Spex'']</ref>
==Characteristics== Spexes are always [[amateur drama|amateur productions]], written and performed by students, and often have a historical theme.<ref name="linkop"/> Other prominent features of spexes are the [[Musical theatre|musical]]-like mix of song (mostly popular hits with new parodic lyrics) and dialogue (often featuring rhyme), and heavy use of satire and parody.<ref name="linkop"/>
One of the distinguishing features of spex as opposed to other forms of theatre is the central prominence of audience participation.<ref name="linkop"/> The audience have established lines, shouting "Restart!" (Swedish: Omstart!/Omtag!) or "One more time!" (Swedish: En gång till!) if they consider the current scene to be of particularly high quality. The actor is then expected to improvise the scene or punchline in a new way. There are also several other commands that the audience can give, such as demanding that the actors should perform the current scene backwards, in slow-motion, or in another language.
While spexes are typically in Swedish or Finnish, at least all Physicist Spex (Fyysikkospeksi, [[Aalto University]], Finland) productions to date have been translated into English for a visiting performance in [[Stockholm]], Sweden. The English translation is now also performed in Finland, to provide the unusual event of a spex aimed specifically at an audience of English-speaking students.
==Gyckel== When performed at a [[Gask]], this form of theatre may be known as ''Gyckel'' or ''jyckel''. A gyckel typically involves a group of students singing a song or performing a play lasting no more than a few minutes. There are several unwritten rules, such as that the gyckel must have been written by the performers and be presented for the first time at the gask. The gyckel should also feature [[sarcasm|sarcastic]] and/or sexist humor.
At a gask with guests from different faculties it is usually expected that each faculty performs its own gyckel. Others may also report that they will be performing a gyckel to the [[toastmaster]], who will then announce when the time has come for a certain group to perform their gyckel.
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Student theatre]] [[Category:Theatre in Sweden]] [[Category:Theatre in Finland]]

{{Infobox person | name = Stjepan Filipović | honorific-suffix = | image = Stjepan Stevo Filipović.jpg | imagesize = | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1916|01|27}} | birth_place = [[Opuzen]], [[Kingdom of Dalmatia]], [[Austria-Hungary|Austro-Hungarian Empire]]
{{small|(now [[Croatia]])}} | death_date = {{death date and age|1942|05|22|1916|01|27|df=yes}} | death_place = [[Valjevo]], [[Territory of the Military Commander in Serbia]]
{{small|(now [[Serbia]])}} | alma_mater = | residence = | spouse = | children = | occupation = | nationality = [[Croatia|Croatian]] }} '''Stjepan Filipović''' (27 January 1916 – 22 May 1942) was a [[Yugoslavs|Yugoslav]] communist who led ''Kolubara Company of the Valjevo Partisan Detachment'' during the 1941 [[Uprising in Serbia (1941)|Partisan uprising]]. He was captured and executed in 1942 in [[Valjevo]]. The photo of him taken shortly before the execution has become a symbol of resistance against fascism in the Second World War. He was proclaimed [[Order of the People's Hero|People's Hero of Yugoslavia]] in 1949. ==Biography== [[File:Mladi Stjepan Filipović.jpg|left|thumb|Young Stjepan Filipović (right)]] [[File:Stjepan Filipović.JPG|right|thumb|Monument to Filipović in Valjevo]] Stjepan Filipović was born on 27 January 1916 in [[Opuzen]] (modern-day [[Croatia]]) as fifth child in the family of Anton and Ivka Filipović. The Filipović family moved throughout the [[Kingdom of Yugoslavia]], so he lived in [[Županja]], [[Mostar]] and [[Kragujevac]]. In Kragujevac, he studied locksmithing and mastered the basics of electrical wiring, carpentry and bookbinding.http://www.starosajmiste.info/blog/stjepan-filipovic-heroj-radnicke-i-antifasisticke-borbe-70-godina-od-smrti/ He joined the labour movement in 1937, but he was arrested in 1939 and sentenced to a year in prison. He joined the [[Communist Party of Yugoslavia]] in 1940. Filipović was commander of the Partisans' Tamnavsko-Kolubarski unit in [[Valjevo]] (modern-day [[Serbia]]) by 1941. He was captured on 24 February 1942 by [[Axis powers|Axis forces]] and hanged in [[Valjevo]] on 27 May 1942, aged 26. As the rope was put around his neck, Filipović defiantly thrust his hands out and shouted "Smrt fašizmu, sloboda narodu!" which translates as "[[Death to fascism, freedom to the people]]!". He urged the Yugoslav people to resist and implored them to never cease resisting. At this moment, a photograph was taken which has since become famous, and from which a statue of Filipović was cast.''A Concise History of Bosnia'', Cathie Carmichael, Cambridge University Press, 2015 {{ISBN|1107016150}}, 9781107016156 page 86Sinclair, Upton; Sagarin, Edward; Teichnerhe, Albert; ''Cry for Justice: An Anthology of the Literature of Social Protest'', p. 438; L. Stuart, 1963. Filipović was declared a National Hero of Yugoslavia on 14 December 1949.Burns, Richard; ''The Blue Butterfly: Selected Writings'' p. 144; Salt, 2006, {{ISBN|1-84471-258-3}}. The town of Valjevo has a statue dedicated to him, "''Stevan'' Filipović". A monument was also erected in his home town of Opuzen in 1968, but was demolished in 1991; reconstruction is planned by the Croatian [[Ministry of Culture (Croatia)|Ministry of Culture]].{{cite news | url = http://www.slobodnadalmacija.hr/Dubrovnik/tabid/75/articleType/ArticleView/articleId/116498/Default.aspx | language = Croatian | title = Pao partizan - Antifašisti će tužiti opuzensku vlast | date = 2010-09-24 | accessdate = 2012-05-09}}{{cite news | url = http://www.slobodnadalmacija.hr/Dubrovnik/tabid/75/articleType/ArticleView/articleId/120526/Default.aspx | language = Croatian | newspaper = [[Slobodna Dalmacija]] | title = Srušeni heroj - Stjepan Filipović vraća se u centar Opuzena | date = 2010-11-06 | accessdate = 2012-05-09}} During the war his two brothers Nikola and Šimun Filipović also died. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{refbegin}} *''[https://web.archive.org/web/20110728031759/http://www.slobodnajugoslavija.org/sloyuknjige/NarodniHerojiJugoslavije.pdf Narodni heroji Jugoslavije]'', Mladost, Belgrade, 1975. {{refend}} {{commons category|Stjepan Filipović}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Filipovic, Stjepan}} [[Category:1916 births]] [[Category:1942 deaths]] [[Category:People from Opuzen]] [[Category:People from the Kingdom of Dalmatia]] [[Category:Yugoslav Partisans members]] [[Category:20th-century Croatian people]] [[Category:Croatian communists]] [[Category:Executed Croatian people]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of the People's Hero]] [[Category:Resistance members killed by Nazi Germany]] [[Category:People executed by Germany by hanging]] [[Category:Croatian people executed by Nazi Germany]] [[Category:People notable for being the subject of a specific photograph]]

revision.text:
{{more footnotes|date=June 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2016}} {{Use British English|date=January 2016}} {{Infobox television | | show_name = The Incredibly Strange Film Show | image = The Incredibly Strange Film Show (1988) Title Card.jpg | caption = Title card of the Show | rating = | runtime = 40 minutes | creator = [[Channel X|Channel X Productions]] | starring = [[Jonathan Ross]] | country = United Kingdom | network = [[Channel 4]] | first_aired = {{start date|1988|8|5|df=yes}} | last_aired = {{end date|1989|10|27|df=yes}} | num_episodes = 12 | num_series = 2 }} '''''The Incredibly Strange Film Show''''' was a series of [[Documentary film|documentaries]] presented by [[Jonathan Ross]] focusing on the world of [[B movie#Psychotronic movie|"psychotronic" or B movies]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tv.com/shows/the-incredibly-strange-film-show/|title=The Incredibly Strange Film Show|publisher=CBS Interactive|work=TV.com|accessdate=19 April 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0237969/|title=The Incredibly Strange Film Show (TV Series 1988–1989)|author=Mister-6|work=IMDb|accessdate=19 April 2015}}</ref>
Each episode was focused on the lives of filmmakers like [[Herschell Gordon Lewis]], [[Sam Raimi]], [[Doris Wishman]], [[Ed Wood|Ed Wood Jr]], [[Jackie Chan]] and many other notable filmmakers who had their own unique style of filmmaking and have made contributions to the world of cinema.
Various movie genres,including such outré types as Mexican wrestling, and Hong Kong horror films were examined in the series, as well.
The series' first episode features interviews filmed at the Senator Theater<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1991-02-02/features/1991033038_1_john-waters-waters-movies-sam-raimi|title='Strange Film' series begins with apt subject: A John Waters interview|newspaper=tribunedigital-baltimoresun|access-date=2016-11-15}}</ref>, in Baltimore, during the premiere of Hairspray. One of the last recorded interviews with [[Divine (performer)|Divine]], as well as an interview with [[John Waters]] (recorded only weeks after Divine had died).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.soapboxoffice.com/2016/11/episode-36-maverick-heart.html|title=Episode 36: Maverick Heart|website=www.soapboxoffice.com|access-date=2016-11-15}}</ref>
The show was originallyf aired on 5 August 1988 on [[Channel 4]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0237969/episodes?year=1989&ref_=tt_eps_yr_1989|title=The Incredibly Strange Film Show (TV Series 1988–1989)|work=IMDb|accessdate=19 April 2015}}</ref><ref name="pulsingcinema.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.pulsingcinema.com/feature/isfs/|title=The Pulsing Cinema - The Incredibly Strange Film Show Episode Guide|work=pulsingcinema.com|accessdate=18 April 2015}}</ref>
A second series - aptly entitled, ''Son of The Incredibly Strange Film Show''<ref>http://www.channelx.co.uk/son-of-incredibly-strange-film-show/</ref>aired the following year. Both series aired in the US on the [[Discovery Channel]] in the early 90's.<aref name="pulsingcinema.com"/>
It was followed by another show, ''[[For One Week Only|Jonathan Ross Presents for One Week Only]]'' which featured filmmakers including [[Alejandro Jodorowski]] and [[David Lynch]].
==Episodes==
===Season 1: The Incredibly Strange Film Show=== {| class="wikitable" border="1" |- ! Episode !! Featured Filmmaker <ref name="IMDB Episode List">[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0237969/episodes?season=1 Season 1 Episode List at IMDB.com]</ref><ref name="theTVDB Episode List">[http://thetvdb.com/?tab=seasonall&id=82924&lid=7 Episode List at theTVDB.com]</ref> !!colspan="2"| First aired <ref name="IMDB Episode List"/><ref name="theTVDB Episode List"/> |- style="text-align:center;" | 1 || [[John Waters]] ||colspan="2"| 5 August 1988 |- |- style="text-align:center;" || 2 || [[Ray Dennis Steckler]] ||colspan="2"| 12 August 1988 |- |- style="text-align:center;" || 3 || [[Herschell Gordon Lewis]] ||colspan="2"| 19 August 1988 |- |- style="text-align:center;" || 4 || [[Ted V. Mikels]]<ref>{{cite book|last1=Curry|first1=Christopher Wayne|title=Film Alchemy: The Independent Cinema of Ted V. Mikels|date=2007|publisher=McFarland|url=https://books.google.com/?id=iLoLffmnu_EC&lpg=PT100&dq=%22Incredibly%20Strange%20Film%20Show%22%20jonathan%20ross&pg=PT101#v=onepage&q=%22Incredibly%20Strange%20Film%20Show%22%20jonathan%20ross&f=false|isbn=9781476603018}}</ref> ||colspan="2"| 26 August 1988 |- |- style="text-align:center;" || 5 || Russ Meyer<ref name=defino>{{cite book|last1=DeFino|first1=Dean|title=Faster, Pussycat! Kill! Kill!|date=2014|publisher=Columbia UP}}</ref> ||colspan="2"| 2 September 1988 |- |- style="text-align:center;" || 6 || Sam Raimi ||colspan="2"| 9 September 1988 |- |}
===Season 2: Son of The Incredibly Strange Film Show=== {| class="wikitable" border="1" |- ! Episode !! Featured Filmmaker <ref name="theTVDB Episode List"/><ref name="IMDB Episode List 2">[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0237969/episodes?season=2 Season 2 Episode List at IMDB.com]</ref> !!colspan="2"| First aired <ref name="theTVDB Episode List"/><ref name="IMDB Episode List 2"/> |- style="text-align:center;" || 1 || [[Jackie Chan]] ||colspan="2"| 22 September 1989 |- |- style="text-align:center;" || 2 || Fred Olen Ray & Doris Wishman ||colspan="2"| 29 September 1989 |- |- style="text-align:center;" || 3 || The Legend of [[El Santo]] ||colspan="2"| 6 October 1989 |- |- style="text-align:center;" || 4 || Ed Wood Jr. ||colspan="2"| 13 October 1989 |- |- style="text-align:center;" || 5 || [[Tsui Hark]]<ref>{{cite book|last1=Morton|first1=Lisa|title=The Cinema of Tsui Hark|date=2001|publisher=Macfarland|page=222|url=https://books.google.com/?id=Hv3yJ6MaoYsC&lpg=PA222&dq=%22Incredibly%20Strange%20Film%20Show%22%20review&pg=PA222#v=onepage&q=%22Incredibly%20Strange%20Film%20Show%22%20review&f=false|isbn=9780786409907}}</ref> & [[Stuart Gordon]] ||colspan="2"| 20 October 1989 |- |- style="text-align:center;" || 6 || George A. Romero & Tom Savini ||colspan="2"| 27 October 1989 |- |}
==Reception== Film studies academic Dean DeFino described the show as "highly regarded".<ref name=defino/> The ''Baltimore Sun'' called it "strangely engaging".<ref>{{cite news|last1=McKerrow|first1=Steve|title='Strange Film' series begins with apt subject: A John Waters interview|url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1991-02-02/features/1991033038_1_john-waters-waters-movies-sam-raimi|work=Baltimore Sun|date=2 February 1991}}</ref>
Director [[Edgar Wright]] claimed that the episode on [[Sam Raimi]] inspired him to become a filmmaker.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Wright|first1=Edgar|title=Hero Worship: Sam Raimi|url=http://www.theskinny.co.uk/film/opinion/hero-worship-sam-raimi|website=The Skinny|accessdate=20 April 2015|date=8 July 2013}}</ref>
==Book== ''The Incredibly Strange Film Book'',<ref>{{cite book|last1=Ross|first1=Jonathan|title=The incredibly strange film book|date=1993|publisher=Simon & Schuster|location=London|isbn=978-0671712969}}</ref> a spin-off written by Ross, was published in 1993.
==See also== *[[Asian Invasion]], a 2006 mini-series with Jonathan Ross talking about the cinema of Japan, Hong Kong and Korea

{{Other uses|Lamb (disambiguation){{!}}Lamb}} [[File:Lambs before Lambs Club 1915.jpg|thumb|400px|The Lambs on June 27, 1915 at 130 West 44th Street]] '''The Lambs, Inc.''' (aka '''The Lambs Club''') is a social club in [[New York City]] for actors, songwriters, and others involved in the [[theatre]]. It is America's oldest theatrical organization. "The Lambs" is a registered trademark of The Lambs, Inc.; and the club has been commonly referred to as The Lambs Club and The Lambs Theater since 1874.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.the-lambs.org/disclaimer.htm |title=The Lambs |date= |accessdate=2014-12-31 |quote=The Lambs, Inc., is America's oldest professional theatrical club. ... The Lambs ® is a registered trademark of The Lambs, Inc., and has been known as The Lambs club for over 137 years. ... |publisher=The Lambs |location= }}</ref>
==History== In 1868 The Lambs was founded in [[London]] by actors, led by [[John Hare (actor)|John Hare]], the first Shepherd, looking to socialize with like-minded people. Several of those, most notably [[Henry James Montague]], came to the [[United States]] and formed The Lambs of New York during Christmas week of 1874. It was incorporated in 1877 in [[New York City]]. Shortly afterward the London Lambs closed.
The club's name honors the essayist [[Charles Lamb (writer)|Charles Lamb]] and his sister [[Mary Lamb|Mary]], who during the early 19th century played host to actors and [[Intellectuals|literati]] at their famed [[Salon (gathering)|salon]] in London.<ref name="Hardee">Hardee, Lewis J., Jr., [https://books.google.com/books?id=i9ujp_4nUEkC ''The Lambs Theatre Club''], Jefferson, North Carolina: McFarland Publishing, 2010 [2006]. {{ISBN|978-0-7864-6095-3}}. A book about the history of The Club. The Lambs was recognized on May 9, 2008, by the Mayor of New York City, [[Michael Bloomberg]].([http://www.mcfarlandpub.com/book-2.php?id=978-0-7864-6095-3 publisher's summary])</ref>
In 1924 they celebrated their [[golden jubilee]] at the [[Earl Carroll Theatre]].<ref>{{cite news |author= |coauthors= |title=Fifty Years of The Lambs |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9B06E3DE163FE733A2575BC0A9609C946595D6CF# |quote=The Lambs, New York's famous actors' club, will celebrate its golden jubilee with a public Gambol at the Earl Carroll Theatre tonight. |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |date=June 8, 1924 |accessdate=2014-12-31 }}</ref>
The Lambs, the [[New York Friars' Club]] and [[The Players (New York City)|The Players in New York]] are often confused. In 1964 long-time syndicated columnist [[Earl Wilson (columnist)|Earl Wilson]] put it this way: "Long ago a New Yorker asked the difference between the Lambs, Friars, and Players, since the membership was, at the time, predominantly from Broadway." It was left to "a wit believed to have been [[George S. Kaufman]]" to draw the distinction: "The Players are gentlemen trying to be actors, the Lambs are actors trying to be gentlemen, and the Friars are neither trying to be both."<ref>{{cite book| last =Wilson| first =Earl| authorlink =| title =Earl Wilson’s New York| publisher =Simon & Schuster| year =1964| location =New York| pages =49–50| url =| doi =| id =| isbn =}}</ref>
==Presidents== The president of The Lambs is called "The Shepherd".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.the-lambs.org/board.htm |title=Governance |date= |accessdate=2014-12-31 |quote= |publisher=The Lambs |location= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150131220915/http://www.the-lambs.org/board.htm |archivedate=2015-01-31 |df= }}</ref> The Club displays the portraits of all its presidents, painted by artists such as [[James Montgomery Flagg]] and [[Everett Raymond Kinstler]].
{{col-begin}} # [[Henry James Montague]] (1874–1878) # [[John Lester Wallack]] (1878–1879, 1880–1882, 1884–1888) # [[Harry Beckett (actor)]] (1879–1880) # [[William J. Florence|William Jermyn Conlin]] (1882–1884) # [[John Riker Brady]] (1888–1890) # [[Edmund Milton Holland]] (1890–1891) # [[Clay Meredith Greene]] (1891–1898, 1902–1906) # [[Thomas Benedict Clarke]] (1898–1900) # [[DeWolf Hopper]] (1900–1902) # [[Wilton Lackaye]] (1906–1907) # [[Augustus Thomas]] (1907–1910) # [[Joseph Rhode Grismer]] (1911–1913, 1917–1918) # [[William Courtleigh, Jr.]] (1913–1917) # [[Robert Hubber Thorne Burnside]] (1918–1921) # [[Albert Oldfield Brown]] (1921–1924, 1930–1932) # [[Thomas Meighan]] (1924–1926) # [[Thomas Alfred Wise]] (1926–1928) # [[Fritz Williams]] (1928–1930) # [[Frank Crumit]] (1932–1936) # [[Fred Waring]] (1939–1942) # [[John L. Golden|John Lionel Golden]] (1942–1945) # [[Raymond Wilson Peck]] (1945–1947) # [[Bert Lytell]] (1947–1952) # [[Walter Noel Greaza]] (1953–1956) # [[William Gaxton]] (1936–1939, 1952–1953, 1957–1959, 1960–1961) # [[Frank Marion Thomas]] (1962–1963) # [[Martin Begley]] (1964–1965) # [[Harry Hershfeld]] (1966–1969) # [[Jack Waldron (actor)]] (1969) # [[Tom Dillon (actor)]] (1969–1986) # [[Richard L. Charles]] (1986–1997) # [[Agustin James Pocock]] (1998–2001)<ref>{{cite news |author= |agency= |title=AJ Pocock |url=http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/latimes/obituary.aspx?pid=160111892 |quote= |newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=September 26, 2012 |accessdate=2016-06-20 }}</ref><!--http://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=156001088--> # [[Bruce Brown (actor)|Bruce Brown]] (2002–2008) # [[Randy Phillips (actor)|Randy Phillips]] (2008–2013) # [[Marc Baron]] (2013– ) {{col-end}}
==Clubhouses== # 1874: Founded and first dinner at [[Delmonico's Restaurant]] (NE Corner of 5th Ave & 14th St.) # 1875: [[Morton House (Manhattan)]] (Union Square) # 1875: [[Union Square Hotel]] # 1876: [[Wallack's Theater]] 848 Broadway (nicknamed "The Matchbox") # 1877–78: 6 Union Square # 1878: 19 East 16th Street # 1880–1892: 34 West 26th St # 1891: [[Gilsey House]], 1200 Broadway # 1892: 8 West 29th St # 1893–1896: 26 West 31st St # 1897–1905: 70 West 36th St (formerly and thereafter known as [[Keens Steakhouse|Keens Chophouse]]) # 1905–1975: 130 West 44th Street (expanded in 1907) # 1975: Guest in [[Lotos Club]], 5 East 66th St # 1976: Current: 3 West Club, 3 West 51st Street, 5th Floor
==128 West 44th Street== {{Infobox NRHP | name =Lamb's Club | nrhp_type = nrhp | image = Lambs-club-128-w-44.JPG | caption = | location= 128 W. 44th St., [[New York, New York]] | coordinates = {{coord|40|45|23|N|73|59|7|W|display=inline,title}} | locmapin = New York City#New York#USA | built =1904 | architect= [[Stanford White]], [[George Freeman (architect)|George Freeman]] | architecture= [[Classical Revival architecture|Classical Revival]] | added = June 3, 1982 | area = less than one acre | governing_body = Private | refnum = 82003382<ref name="nris">{{NRISref|version=2010a}}</ref> }} The Lambs has had many Manhattan homes since 1874, beginning with Delmonico's Restaurant in Union Square. Then in 1875 they met at the Maison Doree on the south side of 14th St. opposite Union Square; 1876–77 next to Wallack's theater at 848 Broadway; 1877–78 at the Union Square Hotel, 6 Union Square; 1879 within a brownstone at 19 East 16th St.; 1880–91 at a Brownstone at 34 West 26th St.; 1891 at the Gilsey House, 1200 Broadway; 1892 at 8 West 29th St.; 1893–96 at 26 West 31st St.; 1897–1905 at 70 West 36th St., what was formerly and thereafter [[Keens Steakhouse|Keen's Chophouse]] remodeled by [[Stanford White]] to be a clubhouse; in 1905 at 128–130 West 44th St., in a house designed by Stanford White, then doubled in size in 1915.
Until 1974 the Club remained at the building at 128 West 44th St. The building was also designed by Stanford White, and was erected in 1904–1905; it expanded in 1915 to include 132 West 44th St. When the club relocated to its current nine-story quarters at 3 West [[51st Street (Manhattan)|51st St.]] adjacent to [[Rockefeller Center]], it sold its own quarters to the [[Church of the Nazarene]] which intended to use the old building as a mission in [[Times Square]].<ref name="NYT2006">Robertson, Campbell, [https://www.nytimes.com/2006/06/02/theater/02lamb.html "Lamb's Theater Company Receives Eviction Notice"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', June 2, 2006</ref> The church leased part of the building for what would become the [[Off Broadway]] [[Lamb's Theatre]] which is not related to the Club except for the name of the building.
The building was designated a New York City Landmark<ref>http://www.neighborhoodpreservationcenter.org/db/bb_files/LAMBS-CLUB.pdf</ref> in September 1974; and was added to the [[National Register of Historic Places]] on June 3, 1982.
In 2006 the Church of the Nazarene sold the building and theatre, which has been renovated by the Chatwal Hotel. They operate a restaurant in the hotel and named it The Lambs Club, although there is no relation between the hotel and The Lambs other than what was left of the building.<ref>Sam Sifton, [https://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/27/dining/reviews/27rest.html "Retro Glamour Made New: Restaurant Review: The Lambs Club"]. ''[[The New York Times]]''. October 26, 2010 Accessed January 31, 2012.</ref>
==Current activity== The Lambs, Inc., is still active in its nine-story quarters at 3 West [[51st Street (Manhattan)|51st St.]] adjacent to [[Rockefeller Center]]. Its members have been instrumental in the formation of [[ASCAP]], [[Actors' Equity]] and [[Actors’ Fund|The Actors' Fund of America]], Screen Actors Guild (SAG) and in the merger that created [[SAG-AFTRA]]. Of the first 21 Council members of Actors' Equity, 20 were members of The Lambs. The meetings to form Actors' Equity were held at The Players, a club similar to The Lambs, because there were too many producer members of The Lambs. The Actors' strike of 1919 was settled in The Lambs, which was referred to as "Local One."
Historically, The Lambs has been the spawning ground of plays, friendships and partnerships. ''[[Mark Twain Tonight]]'' (with [[Hal Holbrook]]) and ''[[Stalag 17]]'' were first performed at The Lambs prior to their national successes.
[[Alan J. Lerner]] and [[Frederick Loewe]] first met at The Lambs, often trying works-in-progress on their fellow Lambs. Loewe left a percentage of his share of [[Brigadoon]] royalties to The Lambs' Foundation. Since its founding, there have been more than 6,000 Lambs including [[Spencer Tracy]],<ref>https://books.google.com/books?id=2ZxE5CUHIUoC&pg=PA112&lpg=PA112&dq=lambs+spencer+tracy#v=onepage&q=lambs%20spencer%20tracy&f=false</ref> [[Fred Astaire]], [[Irving Berlin]], [[George M. Cohan]], [[W.C. Fields]], [[Will Rogers]], [[John Philip Sousa]], [[Conrad Nagel]], [[Fred Waring]] and [[Albert Hague]], and [[Cliff Robertson]], [[Abe Vigoda]] and [[Ken Howard]]. Current members include [[Joyce Randolph]] of "The Honeymooners," [[Jim Dale]], [[Matthew Broderick]] and Tony Award-winning conductor/arranger [[Donald Pippin (Broadway director)|Donald Pippin]]. The Lambs' website contains a listing of its past members.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.the-lambs.org The Lambs, Inc. website] * [http://www.nycago.org/Organs/NYC/html/LambsClub.html "The Lambs Club"] – the NYC Chapter of the American Guild of Organists. * [http://www.nypl.org/archives/4469 Lambs Club records, 1880–1973], held by the Billy Rose Theatre Division, [[New York Public Library for the Performing Arts]]
{{National Register of Historic Places in New York}}

revision.text:
During the run of the [[TV series]] ''[[The X-Files]]'', many [[List of television series made into books|books based on it]] were released, written, including novels based on episodes, a series of comic books from [[Topps Comics]], and many "official" and "unauthorized" non-fiction books.
Some of the novels, which were published in both [[hardcover]] and [[paperback|trade paperback]] editions, came out as [[audiobook]]s read by several of the series' stars, including [[Gillian Anderson]] (Ground Zero), [[John Neville (actor)|John Neville]] (Fight the Future), [[Steven Williams]] (Squeeze), [[Bruce Harwood]] (Skin) and [[Mitch Pileggi]] (Antibodies and Ruins).
Apart from the novels, in 2016 first official ''The X-Files'' [[coloring book]] was released by [[IDW Publishing]].<ref>[http://www.ign.com/articles/2016/02/03/there-is-an-official-x-files-coloring-book www.ign.com]</ref>
==''The X-Files'' fiction== Apart from the following series of books, there has also been a ''Fight the Future'' book based on ''[[The X Files (film)|The X Files Movie]]'', written by ''[[Elizabeth Hand]]'', as well as [[The X-Files: I Want to Believe]] by [[Max Allan Collins]].
=== Juvenile Series (Middle Grade) === <!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:TheXFilesBookSeries1.jpg|145px|thumb]] --> * ''X Marks the Spot'' by [[Les Martin]] ([[Pilot (The X-Files)|Pilot]]) * ''Darkness Falls'' by Les Martin ([[Darkness Falls (The X-Files)|Darkness Falls]]) * ''Tiger, Tiger!, ''by Les Martin ([[Fearful Symmetry (The X-Files)|Fearful Symmetry]]) * ''Squeeze'' by [[Ellen Steiber]] ([[Squeeze (The X-Files)|Squeeze]]) * ''Humbug'' by Les Martin ([[Humbug (The X-Files)|Humbug]]) * ''Shapes'' by Ellen Steiber ([[Shapes (The X-Files)|Shapes]]) * ''Fear'' by Les Martin ([[Blood (The X-Files)|Blood]]) * ''Voltage'' by [[Easton Royce]] ([[D.P.O.]]) * ''E.B.E'' by Les Martin ([[E.B.E]]) * ''Die Bug, Die!'' by Les Martin ([[War of the Coprophages]]) * ''Ghost in the Machine'' by Les Martin ([[Ghost in the Machine (The X-Files)|Ghost in the Machine]])
=== Young Adults Series === <!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:TheXFilesBookSeries2.jpg|180px|thumb]] --> * ''The Calusari'' by [[Garth Nix]] ([[The Calusari]]) * ''Eve'' by Ellen Steiber ([[Eve (The X-Files)|Eve]]) * ''Bad Sign'' by Easton Royce ([[Syzygy (The X-Files)|Syzygy]]) * ''Our Town'' by [[Eric Elfman]] ([[Our Town (The X-Files)|Our Town]]) * ''Empathy'' by Ellen Steiber ([[Oubliette (The X-Files)|Oubliette]]) * ''Fresh Bones'' by Les Martin ([[Fresh Bones]]) * ''Control'' by [[Everett Owens]] ([[Pusher (The X-Files)|Pusher]]) * ''The Host'' by Les Martin ([[The Host (The X-Files)|The Host]]) * ''Hungry Ghosts'' by Ellen Steiber ([[Hell Money]]) * ''Dark Matter'' by Easton Royce ([[Soft Light (The X-Files)|Soft Light]]) * ''Howlers'' by Everett Owens ([[Unruhe]]) * ''Grotesque'' by Ellen Steiber ([[Grotesque (The X-Files)|Grotesque]]) * ''Quarantine'' by Les Martin ([[F. Emasculata]]) * ''Regeneration'' by Everett Owens ([[Leonard Betts]]) * ''Haunted'' by Ellen Steiber ([[Shadows (The X-Files)|Shadows]]) * ''Miracle Man'' by [[Terry Bisson]] ([[Miracle Man (The X-Files)|Miracle Man]])
=== Third Series === <!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:TheXFilesBookSeries3.jpg|65px|thumb]] --> * ''Ascension'' by Quentin Thomas ([[Duane Barry]]/[[Ascension (The X-Files)|Ascension]]/[[One Breath (X-Files Episode)|One Breath]]) * ''Hunter'' by [[Charles L. Grant]] ([[Colony (The X-Files)|Colony]]/[[End Game (The X-Files)|End Game]]) <!-- These books were apparently never published? -->
=== Novels ===<!-- This section is linked from [[Kevin J. Anderson]] --> <!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:TheXFilesNovel.jpg|65px|thumb]] --> * ''Goblins'' by [[Charles L. Grant]] * ''Whirlwind'' by Charles L. Grant * ''Ground Zero'' by [[Kevin J. Anderson]] * ''Ruins'' by Kevin J. Anderson * ''Antibodies'' by Kevin J. Anderson * ''Skin'' by [[Ben Mezrich]]
* ''[[The X-Files (film)|Fight the Future]]'' by [[Elizabeth Hand]] * ''[[The X-Files: I Want to Believe]]'' by [[Max Allan Collins]] * ''The X-Files: Trust No One'' Anthology, edited by [[Jonathan Maberry]]. {{ISBN|978-1-63140-278-4}}. Written by: [[Aaron S. Rosenberg]], [[Brian Keene]], [[Gayle Lynds]] and [[John Sheldon (writer)|John Sheldon]], [[Gini Koch]], [[Heather Graham]], [[Jonathan Maberry]], [[Keith R.A. DeCandido]], [[Kevin J. Anderson]], [[Max Allan Collins]], [[Paul Crilley]], [[Paul Shipper]], [[Peter Clines]], [[Ray Garton]], [[Stefan Petrucha]], [[Tim Lebbon]], [[Timothy Deal]], [[W.D. Gagliani]] and [[David Benton]]. * ''The X-Files: The Truth Is Out There'' Anthology by [[Rachel Caine]], [[Hank Philippi Ryan]], [[Kelley Armstrong]], [[Kami Garcia]], [[Greg Cox (writer)|Greg Cox]] and others.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/X-Files-Truth-There-Jonathan-Maberry/dp/1631405268/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1456160184&sr=8-1&keywords=The+X-Files%3A+The+Truth+is+Out+There|title=The X-Files: The Truth Is Out There|work=[[Amazon.com]]|accessdate=February 22, 2016}}</ref> * ''The X-Files: Secret Agendas'' Anthology, edited by [[Jonathan Maberry]]. Stories by [[Jim Beard]], [[Joh Gilstrap]], [[Lauren A. Forry]], [[Weston Ochse]], [[Yvonne Navarro]], [[Jade Shames]], [[Andy Mangels]], [[Lois Gresh]], [[Jeff Mariotte]] & [[Marsheila Mariotte]], [[Joe Harris (filmmaker)|Joe Harris]], [[Bryan Thomas Schmid]]t & [[Kate Corcino]], [[Ryan Cady]], [[George Ivanoff]], [[Nancy Holder]] and [[Lucy A. Snyder]]. * ''The X-Files Origins'' Series of Books by [[Kami Garcia]] and [[Jonathan Maberry]]<ref>{{cite web|last=Connolly|first=Kelly|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2016/02/22/exclusive-x-files-origins-series|title=Exclusive: The X-Files Origins series to follow Mulder and Scully as teenagers|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|date=February 22, 2016|accessdate=February 22, 2016}}</ref>
===Comic books (trade-paperback collections)=== {{See also|The X-Files (comics)#Collected editions}} * ''The X Files Collection: Seven Stories from the Best-Selling Topps Comics Series'' by [[Stefan Petrucha]], [[Charles Adlard]], [[Miran Kim]] (Berkley Publishing, 1996) {{ISBN|1-883313-10-4}}, * ''The X-Files, Vol. 1'' by Stefan Petrucha, Miran Kim, Charles Adlard ([[Checker Book Publishing Group]], 2005) {{ISBN|1-933160-02-0}}, * ''[[The X-Files Season 10 (comics)|The X-Files Season 10]]'' - series of official continuation comic books, * ''[[The X-Files Season 11 (comics)|The X-Files Season 11]]'' - series of official continuation comic books, * ''[[Millennium (2015 comic book)]]'' - official ''The X-Files'' and ''Millennium'' crossover, * ''The X-Files 2016'' - series of official continuation comic books,<ref>[https://bagandbored.net/2016/04/27/review-the-x-files-1/ bagandbored.net]</ref><ref>[http://www.comicbookresources.com/comic-previews/the-x-files-1-idw-2016 www.comicbookresources.com]</ref> * ''The X-Files Classics'' - series of comic books, * ''The X-Files: Year Zero'' - series of comic books, * ''The X-Files Deviations'' - series of comic books, Issue 1 released March 1st 2017<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.screamhorrormag.com/x-files-deviations-1-comic-review/|title=X-FILES: DEVIATIONS #1: Comic Review - THE HORROR ENTERTAINMENT MAGAZINE|date=2017-03-01|work=THE HORROR ENTERTAINMENT MAGAZINE|access-date=2017-03-02|language=en-US}}</ref> * ''The X-Files X-Mas Special'' - series of comic books, * ''The X-Files: Conspiracy'', * ''The X-Files / [[30 Days of Night]]'' crossover, and others.
